abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is unsatisfactory,
            sustainability unlikely, having attained only modest
            institutional development impacts. While the risks of
            significant lack of follow-through were previously
            described, it would not have been sufficient for this nature
            of operation, where the window of opportunity is small, and
            the benefits lie in maintaining the general direction of
            reform, rather than taking quantum steps. This said, it is
            important that credit amounts be maintained at levels which
            are commensurate with the measures being undertaken. The
            originally proposed two tranche operation might have been
            back-loaded, given the weight attached to conditions for
            second tranche release. However, the increase in the size of
            the first tranche relative to the amount agreed with the
            government, sends wrong signals to the borrower, and reduces
            the credibility of our follow-up operations. In addition, as
            mentioned above, the funds were not used to capitalize the
            National Food Reserve Agency (NFRA), which had been the
            motivation for topping-up. Two areas of the credit represent
            major successes where the Malawian experience may be
            replicable for other countries. The approach of setting up
            an independent revenue authority with a fixed percentage of
            collections allocation for its operations, seems to have
            worked well in providing the motivation which the agency
            needed. Secondly, Malawi's success in privatizing both
            the commercial banks, and petroleum import sector in a small
            market where there is only room for a limited number of
            enterprises, suggests that with setting appropriate rules,
            these can still result in significant efficiency gains. This
            operation underlines the importance of having good analytic
            work as a basis for Bank lending and support to governments,
            analytic work which needs to be designed strategically, to
            avoid the risk of designing conditionality in the areas
            where solid analytical underpinnings already exist, instead
            of focusing on areas which are critical to the overall
            success of the Government's reform program.
